It will have enough firewood for the winter, and enough of everything else for the summer. Nothing would die.<n>Input: If a group of animals could eat, breed, mate, and produce offspring at the speed of light, what would the society of animals be like?<n>Output: It would be a social order. All animals would live under a single command. This would be our society. Humans would live under a different command, but with some of the same rules. Humans have a strong urge to create and control our society, but this tendency can only go on so long before we reach a point where it becomes a conflict between the two commands, which would result in us eating one another or killing each other. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. I think it is likely that the student has been cheating at the examination<n>Output: Professor believes there is no risk.<n><n>Input: What does the expression (a little girl is eating her favorite dessert at a restaurant.  Her mother is waiting for her in the restaurant) indicate? A: She really likes the food. B: She is a very young child. C: She has just reached the ripe age for liking the sweets. D: She is a very greedy child<n>Output: The dessert is being cooked. I have no idea what your interpretation could be.<n>Input: What does (A) indicate? Input: A mother watches her daughter eating some dessert. An adult is eating one of the desserts as well.<n>Output: (A) is true. The child has just reached the age of eating desserts. And the dessert has been cooked.<n><n>Input: Which of the following items represents a good substitute for salt? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n>Output:		 Planet B.<n>This question is a little hard. It's just that ocean is one of the hardest natural objects to define. I'd also suggest asking a physics question for this one; that's really where it lies.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What animal produces milk? Choices:  A: supermarket B: pig C: cow D: refrigerator E: store<n>Output:		 A: supermarket B: Pig C: Cow D: Refrigerator E: Store<n><n>Input: What is the cost of the average car in England? Choices:  a) 10K b) 20K c) 30K d) 50K e) 60K<n>Output: c) 10K b) 15K c) 20K d) 30K e) 40K e) 50K<n>So the final answer would be 10K - 150=<<150/60=80>>80<n><n>In this game I think it is impossible to play this game and not get a full answer. In some respects, it is harder to figure out than Scrabble! This is because it involves two separate questions each consisting of several choices, rather than one.<n><n>The first option is simply (dummy) fill-in-the-blank. With this option all you need to do is select a number of choices that will be displayed based on the answer to the second question.<n><n>You might have figured by this point that it is possible to get a full answer by picking a number of these choices, and it usually does the trick, but it is not foolproof! There are still those rare instances where the game will ask you if you want to add more than one, rather than picking one or two! Let this happen to you!
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What happens when people are waiting for something? How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? She will use the money to raise the child. Can she expect it to be any good?<n>Output><n>(1 + c - d) * (1 + a - e) * (1 + b - c) * (1 + d) = (2 - a) * (2 - c) * (2 - b) * (2 - d)<n>For 2 kids (c = 15 and b = 10) she will add 1 hour to the time it takes her to reproduce (3*a+b) -4*c -8*e +a = 2 hours. Then since she saves $3200 per child, she takes home $100, which means she can have 1 kid after 4 children.<n>Output: $100 - $4100 = $200<n>So in total she will gain $10,000 in 4 generations.<n><n>Input: The price of each kilogram of almonds, walnuts and pecans has increased $2 each since 2007. In 2009 it will cost $3.05, $3.10 and $3.55. How are the prices of the nuts affected by this increase?<n>Output: This price increase only affects the nuts. For the walnuts, however, it increases the price for a 2-kilogram package by $.90<n>(2 - a) + (2 + b) + (2 + c) + (2 + d) = (a - b - c - d) + (a - d - b) + (a - c - d)<n>Thus, the increase in the nut price is $.90/$3.05/$3.55/$3.55/$1.10/5 = $1.05<n>The higher price of walnuts affects fewer customers. Each customer consumes only 5kg. Since the price of nuts increases $1.05, the total amount consumed is $15,080. Thus the average price of walnuts is $0.05/kg, which is $20 lower than a year ago.<n>Output: $15,080 - $1.05 = $14,090<n>So each year customers consume $10,000 ($10,000/year) less than a year ago. Thus a total of $10,000 is now missing from their annual budget. This

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The robot shockingly began to read book after book, it had apparently done what? The choice "E" is for the benefit of the body, as it uses a LOT of energy (energy being a measure of time in seconds) to grow new tissue and muscles, and therefore needs to be exercised more in order for the tissues and muscles to develop the right shape and size (and also helps to maintain them).  For the choice "C", "exercise" is not a factor in your choice, as you cannot "exercise away" the tiredness by simply stopping exercising.  For the choice "D", you'll find it difficult, due to the fact that working out produces a lot of waste product and waste product has to be thrown away after exercise.  For the choice e      You chose "e". We are going to start by giving them a situation and the right answer, and then we will take them through the exercise as they answer the wrong.  The important thing is not how the question is phrased, and the importance of not answering at the first question.  First and foremost, answer the question, then move on to the exercise<n><n>Example:<n><n>John finds his wife is getting increasingly less receptive to their intimacy, and it started on Valentine's Day.<n>He took a one week break, but is itching to get back on.  He went to a gym three times a week, and he spent his energy on cardio and strength.  He also spent a third of his time at the gym warming up and doing cardio.<n><n>The answer for this question:<n><n>Input:<n><n>Output: For their 3 times of the week together, they spend 2.5 hours lifting weights and 1.7 hours doing cardio.<n>They spend a third (1/3) of their time at the gym warming with their cardio, so they have 160 minutes worth of work in total.<n>That sounds like a lot, but their weekly workout was 6 hours total.  Now we are going to take them through the exercise with what is going on in their minds.  The important thing to help them understand is not what the questions are, but their question wording, and how we are all doing.<n><n>Input:<n>Input: This is John and it's Sunday morning. Because his wife is not committed.  B: yes because she is committed to him, she would like to go out on Sunday.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:There is a lot of sugar in what food that fits in your hand? Choices:  A: cupboard B: chocolate C: coffee D: candy bar E: soda pop<n>Output:		 C<n><n>Input: A table of price  at the grocery store is presented. What is the price for each product?<n>Output: $5.00<n><n>Input: A cow is milked several times during its life cycle.  The total cost is $100.  After it reaches old age, it is sold as meat. (You could also argue it is euthanized due to its weak health, but that’s a different question.) A) At the school, Ms. L and Ms. P were planning  for an essay about  the different sides of a story.  Which side do they choose?<n>B) Which side do they choose A)<n>2. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The crowd wasn't that big. Three sit down, one stands. How many people are in the bar?<n>Output: 4 * 1 = 6 * 1 = 10 * 2 = 12 * 2 = 16 * 1 = 16<n><n>Input:There are 5 students. They are divided into 2 groups of 4 students. Which 3 students are in each group?<n>Output: 2 * 2 = 6 * 2 = 10 * 3 * 3 = 12 * 3 = 15 * 2 = 16 * 2 = 16<n>That means there are 6 students in each group, but at the beginning of each group there are 4 students.<n>Output: 6 * 2 = 9 * 2 = 13 * 3 = 16 * 3 = 22 * 2 = 24 * 3 = 30 * 2 = 32 * 2 = 34 * 2 = 36 * 2 = 36<n>Then there are 2 * 2 x 6 * 2 = 4 * 2 x 6 = 10<n>And 2 * 2 x 6 x 6 = 12<n>That adds up to 24<n>That equals 2 * 2 x 6 for 9 x 6 to 15 x 6<n>Now 2 * 2 x 6 = 12<n>And 2 * 2 * 6 = 15 * 6 = 18 x 6<n><n>Input: 4 people walk 4 minutes along a path. One person at a time has to stay on the left side of the path. Can a single person be on both a left and a right side of the path?<n>Output: 2*2 * 2^4 = 16*2 * 2^8 = 24 * 2^9 = 36 * 2^12 = 54<n>Output: 2 * 3 = 8 * 3 = 12 * 6 = 16 * 6 = 18 * 6 = 22 * 6 = 24 * 11 = 32 * 6 = 36* 2 * 8 = 24 x 6<n>Output: 2 * 4 = 6 * 4 = 8 * 4 = 6 * 8 = 16 * 4 = 8 * 8 = 16 * 8 = 16 * 12 * 4 = 16 * 12 = 20 * 12 = 22 * 16<n>Output: 2 * 6 = 12 * 6 = 18 x 4 = 24 * 6 = 32 * 6 = 37 * 6 = 1*5 * 12 * 4 = 12 x 7 = 18 x 5 = 24 x 6 = 36 x 7<n>Output: 5 * 6 = 12 * 5 * 6 = 18 x 5 * 6 = 24 x 5 * 6
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. The best place to keep chickens is either on the coop or in the coop.  The coop is a perfect home for chickens that have been properly housed. The poultry shed is appropriate for animals that go out of their natural habitat and require more space.  If you keep chickens in their natural home, you can use the coop to store things such as milk and eggs, as well as items that are  too small for the house. If you keep them in the coop, do not keep them in their own pen. They would be too small or it would make the coop too small.   The poultry shed helps keep  the chickens warm when the weather gets chilly. The chicken sheds are inexpensive to build and simple to clean. They are also easy to maintain.<n>     The poultry sheds can also be the best way to provide them with food. When chickens eat chicken food (e.g. feed) they cannot go  outside, causing food to get all over the place. This mess will likely cause an illness in the chickens, but without it the chickens will most likely die.  Thus, chickens in their natural environment are  easier to care for.<n>  The poultry sheds can be  used for any family that raises chickens. Most people choose to raise chickens in the coop or the poultry sheds to have a yard full of chickens. This helps the family to enjoy the chickens rather than keep them as pets.  The chickens are not meant to be pets,  but the coop or the shed provides a  better place for them to live than the house does.<n>    Feed   The coop and the hen house supply the  birds enough food to keep them happy and healthy.<n>    Eggs   Chicken eggs provide a  source of food for the chickens. When the chickens  find  other food they become nervous,

So the total of<n>the forces is: 60 x 40-4 = 1200<n>So that is 120 * 40 * 4 = 2000<n>So the total work on a rock is 2000 * 40 x 4 = 2400<n>So the total of work on a rock by pushing it down is 2400 x 4 = 3600<n>So the total of force on a rock is 3600 * 40 * 4 = 8200<n>So the final answer 4<n><n>Input: The number of fingers on your right hand increases by 20 whenever you eat. These can be found in a college application like the ACT, SAT, or GRE, or in a college course like American Lit and Foreign Policy.<n><n>In the academic field, problems are usually more involved, usually more difficult, and more focused. These can be found on college entrance exams or tests, such as the SAT, ACT, or AP.<n><n>In the military, problems can be even more involved and intense, they are often more difficult, and more focusing. These can be found while serving in the military or in one country.<n><n>In the business world, problems can be more complicated, more focused, often more complex, and require greater mathematical ability. These can be found from the Fortune 500, to start-up businesses to high risk investing. In the finance world, there are many opportunities to develop and improve one's mathematical ability.<n><n>In all of the aforementioned, math is always used for basic calculation, such as counting, measuring, and basic understanding about a subject.<n><n>The real-life examples of mathematical problems are usually more serious and more complex than the answers.<n><n>Mathematics - Math<n><n>Mathematics is the study of numbers and their properties. These usually deal with how many things have specific values and how to calculate those values.<n><n>Mathematical problems require the ability to think logically, to apply rules and principles of mathematics, and to use the ability to visualize and analyze data.<n><n>Math is often a foundation to understanding a wide range of subjects in life.<n><n>Mathematistics deals with number operations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and multiplication + division.<n><n>Mathematic concepts usually deals with the study of how a certain quantity, such as number of people, amount of money, or volume of liquid, can change. Also, it deals with the theory and practice of working with numbers.<n><n>Mathematick problems are those that deal with the use of numbers as a base, a concept, an analysis, or an explanation of a phenomenon.<n><n>Mathematic problems can also deal
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:James wanted to stop competing. The explorer moves forward, and stops just outside of the entrance.  The rock structure opens to reveal numerous stone blocks stacked one atop the other. How much did he spent for just his 2 children? Output: $16 x $10 = $((16-$12) * $10.50) = $16*$10=$8.75<n>Input:The second purchased four tickets for his children and also an additional ticket for the tickets for his wife and herself. Choices: a) a shoe store B) a flea market C) a charity shop D) ebay (online)<n>Output: They went to a store (charity shop or charity d ) which only had one size in shoes, and they went to a store in which they were able to buy both colors of shoes.<n>For the shoes they decided that the charity shop was the best choice because they were able to make a purchase right away.<n>Output: 3 shoes<n>That means they purchased 3*2 = 3 shoes.<n>Now, that doesn’t count as four, since they don’t buy any shoes from the store in which they find the first pair of shoes, but they didn’t need 4 because 1 is still 3.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n>Output:		Why might this person would choose to drink beer?  This person believes alcohol is a good way to get drunk.  He or she thinks beer is good for the health to the extent it is used in moderation.  Most importantly, this person believes alcohol is better than getting drunk alone.  Does this person consider each of the above?<n>Output:Because alcohol is a legal substance, this person bought 12 cases of beer.  She or he bought one case of beer for each person in the house.<n>Output:She or he bought 12 crates of beer.<n>For a total of 48 cases of alcohol were bought.  She or he paid for 8 crates of beer.  She paid with a $1000 bill to the bank.  The balance of the bill was $859.<n>For the second case of beer she purchased 2 more cases at the store and paid $859 for their purchase as well.  The other 22 crates were provided by the landlord who gave her a discount.<n>So the total purchase was $543.50.  She gave her $1000 gift certificate to the store to buy a $500.00 set of tires.  The balance of that gift certificate was $39.50.  This person paid with a Bank of America check to the landlord for the balance of the purchase.<n>Output:She paid $79.83 for 22 crates of beer.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n>Output:		 The fox walked from the city, into the forest, where it saw flowers that are not pretty, that are a source of nectar for bees. That's why it had to look for other flowers. Choices: B, A

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n>Output:		 > Sean's body was only 20 pounds leaner than it was before the trip.  What did the change in weight matter to his decisions? A: the reward money. A: His decision B: the hurt feelings. C: If he was found out.  D: How could he get the reward money if he lied about being fat.  E: Problems<n>Output: > The reward money had become meaningless.  In place of it he began going to the gym twice a week.  He also began buying and eating real food.  His diet improved. What made real food more attractive than the reward money to Sean? A: the reward $ would have disappeared soon if he didn't buy real food.  B: If he didn't stay fat. C: How could he get free meals<n>E: Problems<n>Input: Mike was a very nice guy.  He had a very large penis.  He bought the condoms in order to please his girlfriend. What? Options: A: he could go to the store and buy himself some cheap and ineffective condoms.  D: The condoms were free on the Internet<n>Output: > There was no way to get the rewards to the Internet.  In place of the condoms Mike went to the local pharmacy and bought some pills.  He took them on an airplane for his girlfriend before he flew home.  What is the difference between buying condoms and buying pills for Mike? A: condoms weren't available on The Internet.  B: condoms cost money.  C: There was no physical harm done if he took the pills<n>E: Problem<n><n>Output: John had a very nice job in his company.  He did not work hard at all.  So why did he do so badly at work?  Options: A: he was under pressure to be good.  D: His boss was a hard-nose jerk who had only him to blame.  C: His boss was a lazy asshole who ignored him. E: The real reason was because he was bored.<n>You need to pick which is the more likely reason.  Each possibility requires only three choice questions. You can do both.<n><n>Input: David wanted his girlfriend, but after trying to have sex with her, he came to the conclusion he did not want to have sex with her.  He realized her body was "disgusting."  What?<n>Output: > David admitted that before trying to have sex with his girlfriend, he was too hung up on his own
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Though he could've kept going his body appreciated the rest, it had been constantly what during the day? Choices:  A: walk B: lay down C: working D: moving E: exercise<n>Output:		 He did a combination of all three. He ate some sandwiches and also went and did yoga by the river and went swimming after class. These 3 hours add up to 200 minutes total<n><n>Input:A girl is looking to buy 3 pairs of shoes at a retail outlet. She can get in line behind 500 other women who want to buy them, but only the 5 people in line in front of her got to choose the shoes. How many pairs of shoes will she end up with?<n>Output:She will get 3 pairs of shoes.One pair she will wear, then 4 she will store in the trunk of her car after the end of the day.And one pair she will store in the garage, so she has two pairs of shoes to wear on dates, and two more in the closet in case she has a trip to the lake during the summer. So the final answer will be 3+4=8+3+4+3+2+2<n><n>Input:After two days of running around with his friends, Alex had only found two balls near his house.  He decided to come back home and play a round of golf on his favorite course.  He put his clubs up at the top of the stairs and began walking down the stairs, going from floor to floor in an attempt to find the balls.  As he approached the front door he heard a loud scratching sound coming from the ceiling.<n>He went to investigate and located the balls.<n>He began walking up the stairs again, only this time he noticed several other balls that were left behind for him to find.  He looked behind him several times before he looked below him.<n>As he walked down the set stairs again, Alex noticed several small holes that seemed to be cut into the ceiling like a mousehole.  He continued to walk up the stairs, but with each floor a new hole was cut into the ceiling.  Finally, Alex found the end of the chain and proceeded to put two pieces of wood on each hole.  By doing this he was able to hold the roof together which he thought would solve the lack of holes.<n>After several hours of hard work, Alex finally finished the ceiling and was able to get back in his house unaided.<n><n>Input: A student is looking for two pairs of shoes in the market. She only has two shoes and she always goes in the same store. She usually buys a specific pair of shoes or shoes of the same color and size. The girl will never leave the floor with
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Joe suffered many consequences from stabbing a stranger to death.   Among them, the family of the victim did something to him. What was that? Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n>Output:		 he lost his job with the police to another police officer B = job loss + $200 compensation for the crime C = $200 compensation D = $200 compensation E = lawsuit<n>So he lost his job with police B = $200 compensation for stabbing the stranger<n>C = $200 for stabbing the stranger + $200 compensation for his wife filing suit against him<n>E = law suit<n>So he lost his $200 plus the $400 lawsuit against him total $2200.00<n>So the final answer for the choice B for the question was knife wounds.<n><n>Input: A friend wanted to start a restaurant.  He asked his wife for 500-600 cash. She gave him two hundred dollars, but he said he needed more money. What was he thinking?  Choices:  A) Cash B) A credit card C) Check D) Bank loan<n>Output: A) $400 for the restaurant B) $400 for the purchase C) $400 loan<n>So A total of $450 for the restaurant and $450 for the purchase is a total of $800 for 3 meals.<n><n>Input: One week earlier, one person walked into the home of Mary Kay and the other person, her boyfriend.  When one of Marcey's friends walked in and saw that there was a dead baby, she ran to the door screaming "No, he's not here!!!"  She ran outside and yelled into the open window "He got away!"  She then ran back inside and screamed "Did you find him???"  She then ran outside screaming "No, he got away."  She then took off after him screaming "Did you find him!"  She ran down the street screaming "Did you find the baby???" She eventually caught him on video, and he was sent to prison for 8 years<n>Output: He was arrested for making a false report.<n><n>Input: He went out to dinner at a restaurant with Paul last week, but he wasn't paying all of the check. After several years of pay-as-you-go living expenses, Paul gave him his final 50 cents to cover the bill.  The waitress charged the rest of her tips, and after she and her friends walked out, the manager fired Paul.  Which one of the following is the correct answer?<n>Output: The manager did not fire him. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What kind of driving leads to accidents? Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n>Output:		 Which condition is the most common?<n>Input: 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. The most common cause of vehicle accidents?  A: unsafe driving B: unsafe driving C: too cautious D: care not enough E: too much<n>Output: 1. 2. 4. 5 D<n>Input: 1. 0 2. 3. 4 5.  What is the most common error made by drivers?  A: overcorrecting B: under-correcting C: speeding D: cutting across lanes E: over-cutting<n>Output: 1. 4. 1 C<n>Input: 1. 4. 4. 5 C<n>Output: 1. C<n>Input: 1-3. C<n>Output: 3<n>Input: 3<n>Output: 4<n>Output: 4
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What is a person chatting with friends likely hoping to accomplish? Like for example A: 0m, B: 3.5m, C: 10m, D: 23m  The sensor would send an alarm whenever it thinks it is in close proximity to the object, then it turns itself off.  So the final answer is relative proximity<n><n>Input:What does the word cambion mean?  It means 'between the two or three'. Who came up with this phrase?  This is a good question - who came up with this phrase and why are we using it?<n>For instance, let A and B both stand on a three-foot, flat surface.  At a distance of two feet, the sensor detects and alarm sounds as far away as two feet.  At a distance closer to one foot, the sensor sounds an alarm with a range of twenty feet.  As you can imagine, this distance is very large, it is not practical to only provide a two-foot distance. So it was coined for the fact that a distance between two objects is not as big as it is when one object is between two.<n>Output:A cambion is a 'between two objects'<n><n>Input: The word cambion could mean anything, what is the proper word for the word cambion? How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:They decided to hash things out over drinks, after enough booze they were able to get close on a few things and what? Don’t know.<n><n>Input:What is Adam’s total weekly income?  Input: Adam and John set aside $200 for each person to spend on a meal. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n>Output:		  >  >  >  That is not a good reason

Upon returning, all three items were missing from his pocket. When asked what he was doing, the police officer assumed that James had returned to his car after leaving home without leaving anything behind. What could he have done?? That's right, he left his car keys in his car at home - he forgot his wallet AND his phone and his phone was his phone, not his phone. Therefore it was very easy for the police to conclude that James had been on the phone as the driver, and then left home without his wallet and his phone. What could he have possibly been doing? That's right, James is a careless person, who leaves his wallet and his phone at his home to lose consciousness. What could he possibly be doing? That's right - he's stupid. What could he possibly have been doing? That's true - he took his phone with him while driving, so he could make an emergency phone call or use his phone while driving. What could he possibly been doing? That was certainly not "attempting to commit vehicular homicide". What could he possibly have committed? I don't know. He could have gone in for a kiss as if he had just got off work. He could have gone out and got something to eat. He could have stopped at a convenience store for a quick snack. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:It was a great rest, she had never felt this much what in the morning? Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n>Output:		 A<n><n>input:The table below shows three men each being paid $100.50 a week for a two week vacation, and an annual vacation of $30,000.  All of the men wish to take a month off from work.  The first two have already been given the vacation and would not take a leave, but both men want a month off.  The third man has not yet been given the annual vacation, and would not take a vacation, but all three would do so if he was given the monthly vacation.  The following table shows how the wages of each pair of paid vacation would differ from their wages today if they are given the same vacation today.  The salary increases in year one would be negligible, because vacation is only given in the last 2 months of the year.  The salary decreases in year two, because most people take vacation after the second semester of the year.  In year three, salaries remain the same as year one because the vacations are no longer needed by the third and fourth students.<n><n>Output:John wants a month off.  He tells John that he wants a 30,000 vacation. The first three reasons are not listed here as it is not needed. John adds the fourth reason.<n>John wants to take a 12 day vacation beginning May 6.  The first 3 reasons are not needed, and the last 3 reasons are.<n>First three reasons:  The cost of a vacation is $3,000.  The cost of a 10 day vacation is $10,000, and the cost of a 30 day vacation is $30,000, for a total of $10,000.  The total cost for John would be $3,000 * 3 = $60K.  The total cost of the vacation would be $60K * 3 = $120K.  Therefore, the first reason for John saying he wants a 30, 000 vacation is because there will be only 3 students, while the third reason is simply because John wants to take a vacation.<n>Second reason:  The annual salary is $30K in year three, while the cost is $120K in year one.  The total cost is $120K * 3 = $180K in year three and $150K * 3 = $170K in year one. So the first reason is to take a vacation, whereas the second and third reasons are for not taking a vacation in any case.<n>Third reason:  The vacation will go through June 7.  The
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where would you find a bee gathering pollen? He is paid $50 per week per hour for his work.  However, his expenses total $50 per week and he is unable to earn more than $40 per week, hence the reason he has one full time job.  At the same time, he also works part-time.  The only other alternative is to work for free, but he considers that he would loose about $20 per week.  He also believes that paying for extra work would not be enough to sustain his current lifestyle.  The only alternative for John would be to find another job.  But he feels that he is already too old to work as a laborer, and he does not know if he will ever find other work. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The man uses grooming before a job interview, what is he trying to portray? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where is a tabby cat likely to be happiest? Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n>Output:		 If you ask the cat to choose, it will choose a single place to be happy which will be either one of the four locations. If you ask the cat again, it will most likely choose the other two locations as well.<n><n>Input:Where can two people fit three cars in a parking lot? Answer: 2 * width of car = = 8/3x10*width<n>Output: Each car will need enough room to fit the top of the other vehicle in between the two parked cars. So the parking lot will be ~ 10-6 = 240/8=320<n>So the parking lot is ~ 320 * 2 * width = 32 * width<n>* width is the distance between any two points in space

But it's not the most efficient thing to do if her mom worked too (it would take the family twice as much money)<n>Output: My wife still goes to work (her parents still do), but it's less then the dad would have to, which would be less then 1h each week<n><n>Input: The sun rises at 5am in the morning and sets at 2pm in the afternoon. This means that it takes 14 hours for the sun to rise in the east each day and 14 hours for it to set in the west each day. If the sun had never set, it would be 4 hours. The sun rises at 2am and sets at 5am. If the sun never set, it would still be 4 hours.  If the sun had never risen before it set, it would continue to rise. The sun would not change its altitude. If it had not started to rise, and it had started to set before it had started to rise, it would be 8 hours instead of 8 hours. So the sun has always been there.  The sun never sets after it has always been there. It is no more there today, as it is not supposed to be there tomorrow. 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The game was on sale. Or do you wake up before everyone, go to the gym at your normal time and hit the heaviest weights they have? If you have to do something specific at a certain time and on a certain day, do you get disturbed or frustrated by this routine? Is this your daily schedule and if you would like to change it, do you have the motivation to change it? Would this matter to you if you started exercising more regularly?<n><n>Answer:<n><n>The answer that he chooses could also be the correct answer, although it will impact more on his social life rather than his school work.<n><n>Example problem: When you are at work and you go for a 5-minute break... There are other ways you can solve this question, such as time spent at a phone, answering phone calls, checking the internet.

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Give the correct answer(s):   A: the human B: the dogs C: the human D: the towel<n>Output:   >>1-4-8-7D=4 <<4 <<4 <<1-1>>7<1<<7<1 <<1 <<1>>7<1 <<1D:4 <1<<1[...]<n>So the final answer was:<n>D:1 <<1 <<2 <<2 <<1 <<2 <<1 <<1 <<2<2 <<10 << [...]<n>So the final answer, is as follows:<n>E:3 <<3 <1 <<2 <<5 <<9 <<3 <<9 <<3 <<...<n>So the answers are:<n>1D:2 <<1D <<1D <<3 << 2 >> 1 << 1 << 1  E:3 <<1 <<...<n>So the final answer must be as follows:<n>C:8 <<8 << 4 << 4 << 3 << 3 << 3 << 4 >> 4 <<...<n>So the answer is:<n>F:2 << 2 << 3 << 2 << < 1 << 1 << 1 << 1...<n>So the final answers are:<n>1F:2 <<...<n>So the conclusion is as follows:<n>C:-8 << 8 << 4 << 4 << 2 << 3 << 3 <<...<n><n>Input:Which of the following is not a verb?<n>A) Inject B) Move C) Give E) Put F) Say<n>Output: C) InjectD) Make E) Move<n>Output: B) MoveD) Give E) inject<n>So the answer is C) Put<n>So we can use our first principle of logic to determine that C) is not a verb.<n>Output: A) InjectB) MoveC) GiveD) Make<n>Output: F) Say<n>So we can use the last principle of logic to decide that F) is not a verb, either.<n>Output: B) Put<n>So let
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n>Output:		 Attention from people  Attention from others  Attention from other people<n>That's a bazillion points if you use only E so he needs to spend 40/3=<<40/3=>>40 minutes with people<n><n>You can combine your answer, and get multiple choice answers like this.<n>Input: What is the most embarrassing thing you have ever done?<n>Output: What is the best thing you have ever done for someone?<n>Input: What country would you prefer to live in?<n>Output: What should you do if the worst that happens to you is getting fired?<n>Input: Who is a good friend - male or female.<n>Output: Who was the best friend that you have ever had?<n>Input: On what subject should I be learning today?<n>Output: Which is the most important thing to you to do today?  Input: What is the hardest thing about you?<n>Output: Which part of your life do you think you have gotten better at?<n>Input: Who was the best teacher you ever had?<n>Output: Who is a good person to talk to?<n>Output: What's the strangest thing you have ever done with your hair?<n>Input: What would you do if you won the lottery or had $12 million?<n>Output: What do you do every day when you're bored?<n>Input: What is your life motto?<n>Output: What else would you like to learn about today?<n><n>Input:Why did you break up with your girlfriend (Sally)?<n>Output:Why did you date the guy you did for one night?<n>Input: Why did you break up with Sally (the girl)?<n>Output: Why do you like your best friend?<n>Input: What could you do for everyone you love right now?<n>Input: When were you happiest?<n>Output: Where is your least favorite place?<n>Input: When was the best moment of your life?<n>Output: When was the worst moment of your life? So the shelves are: 7 jars to hold 8 jars and a 5th shelf. Add another shelf for jar I, and a shelf for jar J. So your shelves are now: 10 jars holding 14 jars and a 5th storage shelf.<n><n>Input:What is the difference between a jar and a sack?  Choices:  A. Jar B. Canning jar C. Bag D. Container<n>Output: Jar A will hold 10,000 cans. Jar B will hold 500,000 cans. Canning jar D will hold 50,000 cans of peanut butter. So the final answer is 10,000

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What could a balalaika be needed for? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? If you leave out or insert extra notes, you'll be given the same bonus point (unless you answer three times), but each additional note will carry one additional penalty point. If you answer more than two questions and leave out or insert too many notes, the bonus and penalty points are doubled.<n>4) The bonus points are multiplicatively added together.<n>5) If you do not like the way your answer has been interpreted, the penalty points aren't doubled, but your bonus points are reduced by one point.<n>6) The points are deducted even if your answer is wrong. Also, when you have more than four questions in a row with wrong answers, the penalty and bonus points are tripled.<n><n>Input 12:<n><n>Input 14

(2) How many pounds of coffee should have been purchased?  (3) How much coffee would have been needed to make the whole set?<n>Outputs as above.  (1) It is impossible that the total weight of the cup is 4 pounds  (2) How much coffee would be needed to make the whole setup?  (3) The total weight of the entire set would be 5.5 pounds. 4 is correct<n>Output:  You need four cups to make the complete set.  There is no other answer here.<n><n>Input:   Each member of a class has a total of ten students which consists of ten students each of the same grade level with a total of thirty students in total.  The following table compares the total number of students in grades 1, 2, 3, 4 & 6 per class.<n>Output:  The total number of students is 50 students, so 50/10=50<n><n>Input:  This is a 1/2 ounce of cocaine and a 1/2 ounce is usually split into eight ounces each.  So, if the total weight of the drugs was 500,00, the total quantity of cocaine sold was  (500000) / (5250) or (500000).  The total number of ounces sold is 12,000. =12,000/5250=12<n>Output:  If we take the first number and divide it by two, we get 12,000. Therefore, 12,000 divided by two equals 12,000<n>Output:<n>(1) 12,000 divided by 2 equals $12,000<n><n>Input: You will be in a bar in front of your table for the next 4 months. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n>Output:		 [Illinois] for woman A and [Indiana] for woman B<n>So the answer to that question is A<n><n>Input:The farmer who was sitting by himself watching other people was able to pick 3 pounds of corn, at the rate of one pound an hour, how many pounds of corn did he eventually pick?  Input: The farmer who picked 3 pounds of corn was sitting by himself watching the other workers picking corn and could pick 3 pounds of corn at a time.  Output:  The farmers was able to pick 3 * * 100 pounds = 3000 pounds > [3000*3] = 8000 pounds of corn  So the final answer is 7000 pounds<n>Output: 1000<n><n> Input:The farmer was able to pick 3 lbs of corn per hour while a worker was picking a pound of corn per hour.  The person who picked 1 pound of corn per hour did not pick 3 lbs of corn.<n> Output:  The farmer was able to pick 1 * * 100 = 3 lbs of corn per *hour * 3 * * hundred = 3 * 100 x 100 = 3000 lbs > [3000*3 + 1] = 8000 pounds  So the final answer to that question is 10000 pounds<n> Output: 6000, which is less than 1000.<n><n>Input:A. farmer, B. farm workers, C. workers, D. shop workers<n>Output: A for farmer, B for farm workers, C for shop workers AND D for shop workers  So the final answer for this question is 100<n><n>Input: A. farmer, B. worker, C. worker, D. consumer A. consumer B. factory worker  Output: Both answers<n>So the final answer for this is yes  I hope that all the multiple choice questions is easy enough. Thanks for taking the quiz!
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n>Output:		 Execution

As such, a human with their arms folded will have an easier time controlling and making decisions than a human without their arms folded. There has to be like more than 5 correct words on any one line.<n>Also I don't see why it matters whether you're answering on a bus, on a street corner or any road. And yes for answer two (buses) its just because there are a bunch of people in the bus and you would also need to look at it twice, and answer in both questions if you want to.<n>the first question is the reason why i split it in two questions, i didn't realise at first -  so i split it the way i've decided to in most of the questions - just thought i would help. I will definately work on my English on the blog!<n>thanks for the feedback i really want the feedback on here as i like being appreciated!
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:John just made first violin.  This is  is a position on what? Choices:  A: violin case B: symphony orchestra C: class D: learning to play violin E: music store<n>Output:		 John is going to first violin class this week.<n><n>Input:Adam is going to the movie this Sunday. What will he wear?<n>Output: What will Adam wear this Sunday?<n><n>Input:John has a book with over 100 pages.  How many pages does it take for him to read a full book?<n>Output: A person with John’s reading speed must read a book for 7 hours every day.<n><n>Input:What is the best way to make someone happy? A: Gifts. B: words. C: flowers. D: chocolate. E: sex. F: expensive things. G: giving help on difficult tasks. H: going places that are new to you. I: the food you like.<n>Output: John has a food intolerance. He can not eat most fresh foods. He needs to prepare meals each day and freeze some of them in advance. Giving food to John also means that John has to do the household chores. He likes to see the food he makes become a favorite meal for someone else.<n><n>Input:In class John will read 5 pages of a book. On every other day, John gives this book to another person to read. What will it look like if John does this to 10 people? What is the impact of ten John's handing out books to 10 people?<n>Output: John's behavior will be very different depending on which other students were receiving his books. If they are all very close friends, John will treat each of them the same. If most of them are strangers he gives 5 books. If one of them is his mom or dad he gives 3 books. If the two other people are good friends who are very close, he gives 3 books.<n>Output: John's books will be spread thinly. He will read at least 2 books every day. He will take some of the books home in a big box on each trip. However, unlike most people, John will give other people the books at the beginning of the week. If they arrive only one day ahead of the rest of the class he will give only one book. If all have arrived the day late he will only give them a chapter book. At the close of the week John’s behavior will show the effect of giving his books to another person instead of himself.<n><n>Input:John plans to study for 10-15 hours per week. He has 2 classes per week. What are the consequences of him doing that?<n>Output: John’s time

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:For convenience some customers want things straight to the doorstep and use what? (If they were paying the merchant it's actually "C").<n>Output:Which A, B, and D should they use?<n>Output:A, B, and C are all correct answers but not "E".<n>Output:If "B" or "C" were chosen,  there needs to be a "D" chosen that matches what they were looking for.  This answer is the only correct one.  So it is neither for "C" &amp; "D" but for "B" and "D".<n>Output:Which C, D, and E should they use?<n>Answer:  C, D, and "E" are all right answers  BUT  "D" should be used instead of "E" for the right answer.  Otherwise  "D" is not the right answer and "E" is wrong (it should have been "B" or "A".)  The only correct answers are "A" and "D". How much is it worth at the store?<n>Output : You pay $18 for the nuts.<n><n>Input : There are 20 oranges. You buy 10, paying $1 each for each. Now there are 20 oranges.<n><n>Output : $20 + $1 = $12. You buy 10, and pay for them at $1 each. Now there are 10 limes.<n>Output : $20+1.50 = $12.<n>The difference is that both of these answer would include the purchase of 10 limes (or 10 oranges) at the store.<n><n>1. Input: Adam gave 1 million dollars to charity. How much did he give?<n>2. Input: Adam gave $1
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:How can you get in shape if there is no land nearby? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:If a human is sleepy what can they do to feel more alert? Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n>Output:		 Dreaming is the best way to remain alert.  If our mind is sleepy we have to choose A or B or D or E.<n>So if we choose Dreaming we have to have the following choices after sleeping:<n>A) wake up<n>B) wake up again for 60 seconds<n>C) stay asleep for more then 30 s<n>D) get up and do something else until your mind is awake again (20 is a good limit)<n>E) continue sleeping or lie in bed until you become sleepy again<n>So the answer is to always choose D or E after sleeping.<n>So the final guess is 56.<n><n>Input: If you were asked to estimate how many days it will take to make 50 000, the answer is: 6+6*36=84 days<n>Output: Do the sums in each row correctly or you will not be allowed to continue.<n>So, first column:<n>> 84 Days<n>> 6*36=42<n>> 144 Days<n>> 36*48 = 120 days<n>Next row:<n>> 64 Days<n>> 36*50=168 Days<n>> 72+48=192 Days<n>> 24*12=320 Days<n>If you get the numbers all correct you are entered into the draw to win $2000 in shopping vouchers.<n><n>Input: A is 15 and B is 13.  You were shown a small box and asked to estimate the size of it.  Your best guess would be about 5 inches long and 1.5 inches deep.  What is the correct answer?<n>Output: Both numbers will be correct (i.e., you will be correct), hence the draw is held.  Good luck.<n><n>Input: On a train there were 5 persons, and at a stop there was a door. A young man asked the other 4 people in the train what the door did...<n>Output: You did not understand this question, because either you were not aware that this was a door or you did not think the train was a public transportation.  Therefore the question is no longer valid.<n><n>Input: One child has a stick which the others put in it. Another child then takes the stick from the child who placed it into the other child. And the third child takes the stick which had been put into the other child and puts it into the stick which had been placed in the child who had put it into the child who had put the stick into the child whose stick had been in the child who had placed the other child's stick

Now if the ficus is at the window, that's not a good idea.<n><n>Feedback: I think you don't know what the word "brighten" means..<n><n>Here is some info....   I have a 5' ficus about 15ft tall on a desk in my office.   It's not very bright because it's close to the window...  But it doesn't smell bad.  It's in a glass pot, but I don't water it for at least 6 weeks.  The thing does have lots of leaves so it's not getting so little water that it's drying up and going to fall out.   The leaves are more yellow than green, which I like.  When you look at them they're not perfect and don't have a great shape, but even so...  It's never looked less like a ficus than it does.   It's been here for a while, maybe a yr or more now.  Maybe a few weeks more, but not many.  Still...  it doesn't look like a ficus.      Any takers??

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:After going for run you have a sense of what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: flying C: sweating D: falling down E: trip<n>Output:		 satisfaction satisfaction satisfaction satisfaction

If the soccer player missed to a few meters, he will continue to fall down.<n>Input: There are 3 holes. One hole is on the bottom, one hole is on the top and one on the side. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where would a ticket help you to get to a different country? Choices:  A: train station B: baseball stadium C: lottery D: movie E: bus<n>Output:		 A train ticket is a ticket to a different city or even a different country. Ticket = Trained<n>A lottery ticket is a ticket to the same city twice. Ticket = Ticketed<n>A movie ticket is a ticket to see the exact same movies as everyone else at the theater. Ticket = Ticketed

If there was a study room, then C. If there was a dining room with a kitchen, then D. If there was a utility room, then E.<n>Output: If there is one room with a bathroom and another room with a toilet, then D.
