Kennedy<n>Output:He was the second human being to discover a way to cure HIV/AIDS<n><n>How did this answer relate to this week's question?<n><n>Input:On July 8, 2015, NASA launched the Juno spacecraft toward Jupiter. It is expected to arrive in 2021. It has a mission duration of seven years  Input:How long does it take for Juno to go from Jupiter to Earth?<n>Output:The spacecraft takes 13 years.<n>On average, 13 years is how long it takes to make one full trip to Earth, and the time it takes to make one trip between Earth and the Sun is 691 days<n>So, in total, the answer is 7 years<n><n>Input:Who won the Nobel Prize for Physics in 2010? How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? Choices:  A: relax B: dreams C: have nightmares D: restlessness E: snore<n>Output:		1: He gets at least 6 regular hours of sleep, with 3 hours as a rest day. 2: He has a sleep disorder where he does not fall asleep until 11 or 12 in the night.<n>3: He has a sleep-related disorder in which he only gets about 5-6 hours sleep per night. 4: He does not sleep because he fears waking up during his day.<n>He is allowed to have snoring or restlessness without falling asleep immediately after waking up.<n>The snoring allows him to use his voice in conversation.<n><n>Input:What is the probability that when an old person visits a new doctor, the doctor will be an intern?<n>Output: 1/2 + 2/6 = 4/24<n><n>Input:The best way to lose weight is to eat only healthy foods, and limit your exercise to walking. What are the results he gets from the plan?<n>Output: 1 lb lost per week +.5 lb weight loss per week x number of weeks in plan = 1 lb per month<n><n>Output: The more you exercise, the more you lose in comparison to the people who jog. How does that differ from simply eating a low-fat diet?<n>In most instances exercising works best. This suggests if you exercise (in the gym) you will lose more weight.<n>Exercise helps you burn calories, increasing the amount of weight you lose<n>By limiting the amount of exercise you do you end up burning less calories, and therefore the more weight you lose in this type of routine, the faster you lose the weight and the more slowly it will regrow (since there is less time to work out)<n>Exercise should be your first and only dietary priority because it can lead to weight loss, you burn more calories eating an exercise routine<n><n>Input:Adam walks at least 100 feet every day, and walks with a goal to walk more each week. What is his goal pace?<n>Output: 5mph x 5 x 100 is 5.3 mph<n>The maximum mile that he walks in a given week is 100 ft. per day.<n><n>input:Which of these statements is true for a 5-year-old girl with the condition cerebral palsy?<n>Output: It is more likely that a 4-year-old child will develop cerebral palsy than a 5-year- old.<n><n>Output:The amount of salt in food is often considered to be a factor in diet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n>Output:		 None of the above<n><n>Input:For a year Adam lived in a single-room-occupancy hotel with his father on a construction site in Los Angeles. Adam's father worked full time while Adam worked part time repairing his father's mobile home. The total rent was $2,700. The room was a shared room with 10 residents.<n>There was a kitchen, a bathroom, and several rooms for storage and laundry. Each tenant paid $35 a month.<n>The room came with a refrigerator and microwave, a coffee maker, and one dishwasher, a telephone, and cable television.<n>The bathroom came with a shower head and an ironing board, a hair dryer and hair brush, a toothbrush, a toothpaste tube and toothpaste dispenser, a shampoo dispenser, and a facial scrumaker.<n>There was a clothes line next to the shower for clothing, and additional clothes were stashed in the room. The clothes were hung by a hook on the wall next to the bathroom door, and each occupant wore their own clothes when they left.<n>The property manager charged $20 nightly per room per person. The room fee was based on the number of persons who lived in the room as well as the size of the room. Rents ranged from $60-$145 per month.<n>The apartment was on a commercial construction site next to a highway with several road crossings. The construction work was extensive.<n>Adam chose the apartment on the basis of its location adjacent to the highway. The road crossings were located close on both sides of the road. This was a convenient location for emergency vehicles in the event of a traffic accident.<n><n>Input:Adam worked for years as a general contractor in Los Angeles and earned a college degree in electrical engineering from California Polytechnic State University.  He has held several positions at various companies.<n>Adam's responsibilities included designing and building new electrical substations, construction projects managing crews, installing and monitoring electrical and telecommunications equipment, and constructing and improving underground facilities.<n>He was a director of multiple construction companies and a major employee of several other companies.<n><n>Output:During most of the time that Adam worked, he made an average salary of $50,000 per year.<n><n>Input:Diana purchased a two-bedroom apartment in Los Angeles. The rent was $2,200 per month. It was about an 80 minute walk to the bus stop with a 15 minute walk to a supermarket.  Diana's mother worked as a nurse at a private hospital
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n>Output:		 She was a bit of all four<n><n>Input:Rafay is at a wedding where someone goes by the name of Bibi or Bimbo. She was the person's escort into the wedding.  One of the people who he was supposed to escort was named Adella which was his nickname.  One of the wedding guests asked, "What is your family name?"  Rafay answered, "I do not have a family at all,  I've always been alone."  He continues, "I was born in Afghanistan and raised by the tribesmen until I was 10. Then my grandparents and family moved to Turkey."  Adella then asks, "Why are you staying in Turkey?"  Rafay answers, "My mother died when I was 5 and had to move back here with my aunts, uncle and my grandmother. Now I want to escape."  Adella laughs and tells him, "You're not going anywhere! You can stay here with us until you're 18."  Rafay laughs and shakes his head.  He says, "Forget all that, come to Russia with me. I want to go to Russia, you can go too, if you want."  Adella then tells him, "You can't go to Russia without me. It won't be the same without you."  Then Adella grabs his hand and pulls him down the street.  They walk side-by-side.  Adella smiles, waves at people,  and then pulls ahead of him, "Bye, Raf!"  And then Adella leads Rafay into some bushes near some buildings. Rafay then asks Adella what he's doing? He says, "We are going to get married."  He goes on to describe Adella's plans for the future to Rafay.<n>The first item on Rafai's to-do list is to get married.  He then tells Adella that the day that he moves to Russia he's going to marry Bibi, Adella's full name, and  she will have two children<n>The second is to learn how to drive a car.  When he gets a car of his own he will begin driving it around the city. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:When people want to watch a new move, the often go see it at the? Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n>Output:		 Adam goes to the gym 1x a week<n>Adam goes to the gym 2x a week<n>Adam only watches moves once<n>Adam only goes at night<n>Adam only sees the movie in the movie theater<n>So the final answer for town B is A<n>Adam is currently watching all the movies in the theater<n>Adam did not see all the movies at the theater<n> Adam only went to the gym 1x per week<n>Adam only watches the movie in theaters 3x/week<n>So the final answer was 2<n>If you are an accountant working at the theatre, and you put the ticket on sale, you spend that ticket on theater expenses. This is actually the case for all of theaters. If you put the ticket on display, you spend that ticket (along with advertising etc.) on the actual show. Hence, the total of all those expenses would be 5, equal to the amount Adam bought (the tickets)! I don't think we are far apart for "Theater/Movie Theater."<n>I actually had this question in a midterm, one of those where you didn't have to use any common sense. I got an 86 on that one.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where do you buy treats for kids over a counter? Choices:  A: candy store B: butcher shop C: kitchen D: auto repair shop E: post office<n>Output:		You find 5 children and feed them each a candy bar on the counter (3/5=1%)  and then pick 5 items that they can take home from there. You each pay $.75.  Each food purchase has an interest charge of 3% and so costs $2.25.  If you spend $1.00 each time then all of you will see a profit (plus the interest) of $1.75=$1.75*5=$4.50.  If you can each bring home a full-price item then you make $15.  If you sell $2.25 worth of candy bars then your customers make a profit of approximately $15, giving you a profit of approximately $1.25<n><n>input: In order to win the lottery, is it necessary to buy at least five lottery tickets?<n>output: No, you can win the lottery without buying a ticket.<n><n>Input: What is the square footage of our office in New York City?  If we have an existing office in our current building, what are the square footage requirements to expand in the same room?<n>output: The space of the existing office is 60,000 square feet. We need an additional 16,000 square feet.  Therefore, our space requirements are 60,000 + 16,000 = 160,000 square feet.<n>The answer is 160,000, which is the square footage of a one-bedroom apartment in a Manhattan building.<n><n>Input: In a two-bedroom apartment rent is $600 a month. If you would like to move into the opposite bedroom, would you have to spend $1,400 or just save up more cash?<n>output: Just save. If you want to share money with someone you have to pay back the principal.<n><n>Input: Which of the following states has been hit the hardest by hurricanes?<n>Output: Florida.<n><n>Input: The sun rises only during the summer.  People need food for energy which is only available from the sun's heat.  Therefore, the demand for food is always increasing during summers.  This means people need meat to survive summers while some people need fuel to burn for heating their homes to survive winters.  The result is that the consumption of meat and fuel are increasing at the same time.<n>Output: Energy demands would rise so that meat consumption would drop and so energy consumption would decrease.  Since supply and demand don't decrease at the same time, there would be no winner in food
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:When going to sleep what noise does a human make? How do you do this?<n><n>#20, #24, and #31 are both the same answer if we answer them both in minutes. The problem is we have to have known that before we did any searching for a more correct answer. For example, a person who says they do not like apples might also say that they do not like oranges, so we can not conclude that they have never eaten an orange. We have to do some searching before answering, not just a one question.<n><n>If someone tells me the answer is C, I am going to assume that they know it is the correct answer anyway. If a person says its D, I am going to say lets just move on to answering E. If someone says that its E is incorrect then I will say oh well.<n><n>As I think about it, I'm going to come down with a definite answer as to A,B, and C. I'll leave it at that.<n><n>Input: A. A. D E  (1-6-7)<n>Output 1-2-3-5-7-11-13<n><n>Input:  The second to last question is to do with a particular object, not an entire subject. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The police man was waving flares, what did he do with the impatient car? Choices:  A: book robber B: he had a word with the driver. C: believe guilty D: direct traffic E: wave on<n>Output:		B<n>He asked the car to stop  He told the driver sorry, no cash and keep going the wrong way   The police man decided to arrest the man when the car continued to drive in the wrong direction  He told the driver the police were on their way, the door was open and he waved good day   He walked past the car while waving good day and gave the driver a "welcome"
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by many people recently? Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n>Output:		B<n>For every 10.4 pounds of an "other" people breathe, 100.5 pounds of air can be found. How much people breathe depends on what they breathe.<n>Input:Which country was the largest consumer of wood in the 1930s?<n>Output: China B<n>For every 10.0 pounds of an "other", the world consumes a total of 0.02 pounds. How much people burn wood depends on what kind of wood they burn. How much wood people burned for cooking depends on where they burned it. If cooking happens in a wood stove in the same building as the kitchen and the stove is not moved, wood can burn indefinitely. But a fire can quickly get out of control if it heats one or both rooms too quickly. Wood stoves are also easy to steal because cooking smells so good. This problem can be resolved by keeping the burning area completely dark.<n>Input:A typical household water bill represents the cost of water service used to clean and treat the water. By comparing household water bills from different households and from the same household more than a year apart, it is possible to calculate water bills for the majority of people who live in the United States.<n>Output:<n><n>If you add all of the people who have ever eaten that one meal in a time period you consider, do you find that they actually spend more than the time at the restaurant?<n>In reality, if you do not count the hours spent washing food off the plates, or the hours spent cooking it, the actual cost of food in the restaurant is probably less than what is on the menu.<n><n>Input: What type of music can you hear when you walk along a sidewalk when there is just a mist of snow on the ground?<n>Output:A) classical B) folk music C) country music D) popular music E) disco / rock<n>For every one ton of snow you add, there is about an 8.6 ton of music that is created by it.<n>Input:What does a typical man consume, the rest of his life and most of his life, for food? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What does a judge do when someone is convicted of a crime? Choices:  A: conduct trial B: arrest C: bring in verdict D: pass sentence E: serve justice<n>Output:		 What can be inferred from this question? That a judge does conduct trials and arrest. It also mentions that he can bring someone in for trial as well as give a verdict. How is the question worded? If not, what should the question be worded as?<n><n>In your country, what is the penalty if the man is found guilty of stealing his wife's belongings? In this case the penalty was imprisonment for 15 years (I think) but what if the man did not take the belongings? In that case he would be fined 3/3 of the value of her belongings. Now what if the man did take the belongings? What would the penalty be for not taking it?<n><n>What is the difference between a "penalty" and a "fine"?<n><n>A penalty is something that people can pay. A fine is not something like a wage or something. A penalty is worth more than a fine.<n><n>Fines differ from a penalty in that they are usually set amounts like 2/3 of the value (and sometimes less than that) and then there is the matter of a sentence (which is more of a punishment than a fine).<n><n>In which of these sentences was a sentence less than a "fine" and which one was more than a "fine"?<n>1. A sentence of 2/3 of the money spent. This means 2/3 of the "fineness" of the item.<n>...and in the cases that the sentence was actually a fine, the amount was so much less than the value of the item, that they were even considered a "penalty".<n>2. A sentence of 2x the maximum amount possible for the crime - this can be a sentence like a one year conditional sentence, or a sentence like a 6th degree sentence.<n><n>A fine must be paid by the recipient or the court, not necessarily the person convicted. As I understand it, a fine can be any monetary amount one is allowed to pay. The difference is who pays it and whom gets it.<n><n>In what situation would a fine need to be paid to someone other than the person who brought the fine - if he paid it himself and the money came from some kind of government fund for victims?<n><n>The punishment must come from the government and the victim. In some (I'm sure there are many) ways the punishment may be a fine, a prison sentence, a tax, a fine in the amount of the price of the item, or maybe even just a deduction

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n>Output:		 It is at ___________ (the orchestra)<n><n>Input: __________ tells you the name of the piece, its key, and any other information. Then it asks what key it is written in. Then it looks up the composer. If the composer was a major composer of the era the piece was composed in, then it looks at the piece's score. If the composer was not major, it looks for the name of the composer of the piece itself. It looks up if the piece is part of a series of works like the Symphony, Largo, etc.  Then it asks what the first few bars of the piece are called.  If it's a Largo, it would probably start before the 1st and go on until the 2nd.  If it's the First, it would start before the 1st but would progress until the 2nd.<n>Output: __________ was written by Robert Schumann<n><n>Input: _______ will look up who wrote the score, composer and composer series. ____________ will look up any connections between the composer and the piece.   That's all that it takes to find the name of the composer if the piece is not a part of a series.   If it is part of a series, ____________ will look for the name of the series.   If the composer was not a major of the era, it will look at the name of the composer himself.  Then it pulls up the name of the composer in that era.  At the end it can use a lookup table that gives you the chords the piece is in.  It should get to the end of the list (the part that says composer) pretty easily, since it's not hard to figure out who was the composer.<n>Output: ____ was written by _______.  _______ is usually the composer.<n><n>Input: What was the name of the writer of the _______? _____________________ _______<n>Output: ________ _________ _______ _______ _______ was written by __________ _____________________ _______ _______ and _______________ _____________________ _______ was written by<n>Output: _________ _________ _______ was written by Robert Schubert   Robert Schubert was not a major composer but he wrote some of the pieces for the piece _________ __________ _________ was written by _______________ _______________________ was not.<n><n>Input: Robert Schubert wrote 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? Choices:  A: manipulate B: charming C: deceive D: exaggerate E: incompetent<n>Output:		 to gain her trust the realtor was: A: charming B: manipulating C: charming D: exaggerating E: incompetent<n>The realtor was charming and charming and charming... But she wasn't very good with manipulation.<n><n>Input:To be able to play the guitar correctly, the musician must know how to play the right notes.  In this situation what skills did they have?  In another: to get into a restaurant you had to show:       * proof that you had money.  * your birth certificate  * passport of either the United States or Australia  * a copy of your school diploma  * utility bill of either the United States, Australia or Canada.  * a copy of you bill with the name of your company on it      What was wrong with the answers you got?      "The right note" was "piano", not "guitar".  Or "right note" is "right" and "prove".  Or all of them.      Note: In the second example, the musician did not show proof of money, only of birth certificate.     E: To be left with only two options: to be dishonest or not to be dishonest.  That's it.  No question.<n>Output: How well an actor knows his lines and expressions.  You had only two options: to say "you did very well" or to say "you did not well".  That's it.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where are small grapes used? Choices:  A: picnic basket B: wine press C: juice D: fruit cocktail E: kitchen<n>Output:		 The grapes are used to make fruit cocktails.  The juice is used to make vodkas<n><n>Input:Johns goes to the gym 3/5 days a week. He spends 1 hr each day lifting weights. Additionally, he also works out 20 minutes per day in the gym. He spent 1 hour each day lifting weights. The gym was used during his working hours. Jack's time at the gym was also spent exercising 20 minutes per day in a gym that was open during  his working hours.  Therefore, Jack could not determine the total amount of time he spent working out at the gym per week  Therefore, the answer is A<n>Output:A<n><n>Input:Where is small grapes used? Choques: A: picnic basket B : bottle of wine C: juice D:  (fill in the blank) E:  fruit cocktail<n>Output: The grapes were used for the fruit cocktails. The juice was used to make vodka<n><n>I'm going to try something new:  In addition to doing "homework" on the answer,  I'm going to post my answer in the first line of every question that is not directed toward solving the multiple choice homework. This way, the problem can be viewed in many different ways and, hopefully, help everyone learn.<n><n>First I want to say that my name is John. I'm 10 years old. The year is 2008 and I am in grade 5. This is just a discussion question because I'm not quite sure what to answer. I need to know how many hours a week do you spend doing things in your life.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Remembering past successe is likely to cause what? Choices:  A: problems B: crying C: inspiration D: trauma E: nightmares<n>Output:		 Remembering past success is likely to cause problems.  Choices: B.  If the past success was not successful then it will cause trauma and will give flashbacks.  If the past successes was good then it will make you inspired.  If the past failure is not good so it is highly unlikely that they will give you inspiration.  Choices:  C.  If the success was not successful you will find out why it was not a success.  Choices: E.  If the success is bad then they will feel hopeless and give you nightmares.  If the success does not give any reason so it is highly unlikely to have nightmares.  Choices: D.  If you can't remember the past successes then you will never solve your problem.  Choices:E.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:A person would carry a large netted drawstring bag to what sort of place? Choices:  A: airport B: car C: jewelry store D: garbage can E: laundry room<n>Output:		 B to C to D to E, the netting is used to stop garbage from sticking to clothes.<n><n>Input: If you give a person $1000 and a pair of sneakers to go places, if they wear only $1000 of them, what would they use that extra $1000 for?<n>Output: If they don’t wear the sneakers and they wear another pair of sneakers, the rest of that $1000 would be a gift-in-kind to a charity of their choice.<n><n>Input:<n>A person who drives a car for four hours would get $240 worth of fuel. A person who drives a car an hour would get $4 worth of gas. A person who drives half an hour gets $8 worth of gas. A half hour drive gets $16 worth of gas. The amount in the envelope will be $10 at the end of the transaction. What happens to the $10 when the bill returns?<n>Output: A $100 bill is returned to the person who left it.<n><n>Input:What is so great about a company that pays its workers with Apple gift cards? What is so great about a McDonald’s store that pays its workers in gift cards? What is the greatest positive thing about a company that makes toys that children like to play with? What is the greatest negative thing about a company that sells candy?<n>Output<n><n>Assignment:<n>Find how many hours a person should spend exercising per week.<n>Answer(s) and Comments:<n>It’s usually better to try to estimate how long you think a person should spend exercising each week than to try to guess how long they actually do it. If someone works out 5 times, and they estimate how much time they put in, that works out to about 35 minutes for each exercise activity. Now, if the exercise takes 40 minutes, then they estimate how long it took to work out 2 hours, and that works out to about an hour per hour of exercise. Those estimates are reasonable—it’s always better to get information from people than
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? Choices:  A: diary B: city C: bible D: graffiti E: labyrinth<n>Output:		 Diary D city B scripture graffiti E labyrinth<n>Now that you have a list of passages that you're not going to write down, you should find a journal that you might write in, such as a notebook.<n>Now that you have written down your passages and the notes that you're going to take, it is time to write your essay.<n>In order to write your essay, first you should decide what you are going to write about. Then you should develop a thesis statement from that. You should think about your idea about 30 to 60 minutes before writing.<n>Now that you know what you're going to write about, your next task is to decide whether to write an essay in your journal or on a page in your papers.<n>Write on your paper as you would write in your journal. Do not try to "write" on your papers in your journal because your thoughts will probably be less coherent.<n>As you write your essay, be sure to write down your conclusion, because you may not know where to go with it.<n>Your conclusion is a short sentence that summarizes everything that you just wrote about. Write your conclusion in one thought and then work on your final draft as you would for any other assignment.<n>After you have finished writing your essay on your journal, come back to it.<n><n>Input:How long should a sentence be?  Output: 30-45 words.<n><n>Input:Name one sentence that you wish you didn't write, or that you wish you could, but were unable to.  Output:1) Don't have sex tomorrow - That would be silly<n>2) The man on Mars - It might never come to pass.<n>3) I'll never see the light of day again  - I got the answer wrong.<n>4) Who is that man? - He doesn't look like any man I know.<n>5) We've got to be smart if we're going to fly a ship the size of a planet.  - Someone else wrote it.<n>6) I'm worried about these new people.  Are they really our friends?  - They don't have to be if we're smart enough to figure it out.<n>7) I don't see any future in this.<n><n>Input:What do you think would make up a successful program?  Output: Successful programs would have to have an emphasis on social skills in children and provide good educational opportunities.<n><n>Input:Your idea to address a social problem would either be: 1) Teach

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:She had been applying for job for weeks with no call back, she knew she was qualified, so what did she feel? Choices:  A: employment B: frustration C: stress D: working hard E: love<n>Output:		 A<n>Question has two answers:1) you could get a job in a second to make some money. 2) you have to keep applying or start looking for a new job. Do you think about changing jobs often or trying to work on your resume?<n><n>Output: The above is a test. Each answer is a fractional number. For the fraction of second before the person gives up will be 10.<n>A person can give up in the fraction of a second of time that it takes to type in the correct answer.<n><n>Output:You just saw a movie in a mall. When it was over, there was a short interval before the next movie was offered. After the interval, the person was back to looking at the movie ads. Which one would you have chosen?<n><n>Input: You had to write 20 sentences about a book of yours. It is a mystery fiction book.<n>Output: The author of the book was Bill Gates. Why do you think he chose this book?<n>Question has two answers.<n>1) Write a review of Bill Gates books<n>2) Write a review of what type of books do you write<n><n>Input: What happened to his house? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What has highly criticized security? Choices:  A: university B: concert C: home D: terminal E: airport<n>Output:		<n>A: university<n>C: concert<n>E: terminal<n>D: airport<n><n>Input: What is John's job at work?<n>Output:He is the head football coach for football team A<n>C: home<n>D: terminal E: airport

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What would be considered a success when attempting procreation? Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n>Output:		 A, B, C, F<n><n>A is the wrong answer, so this should be A. So what should be considered a success? Because I think a success should at least be good for you, rather than being the end of your life.<n><n>Output:<n><n>A is the correct answer so it should be F. The choice should be C.<n><n>Output:What should the difference between 'average' and'superior' look like?<n>A has better question structure than the other choices, but a superior option would be that it is more relevant and has good structure as it has 2 parts and 1 whole. I agree.<n>B is the correct answer<n>C is the correct answer.<n><n>Input:What is the average time it takes you to prepare food by cooking?<n>Output: 0.45<n>So it would take 4 hours and 25 minutes to cook a batch of pasta<n>So the correct answer is 4<n><n>Output:What would most attract you to a relationship?<n>The fact that he is attracted to you too  would be a good indicator of a good relationship.<n>A great date usually starts in the first 10 minutes, and can get more interesting after that.  If it ends quickly then it probably isn't that special. But if it goes long and ends with someone saying "I don't really feel like doing this" then that usually is a sign of a good relationship.  Good dates with really great people take time, and usually you can tell if one really has a good relationship with someone. If they don't laugh at each other when jokes are made, then it's probably not a good relationship. If one says that one "needs a break" after dating for a few months, then don’t waste your time with the one. If you don’t want to do the things the other person does but still want to hang out then that is a good relationship. It's kind of like dating, but at the same time, a relationship in this case is more like work. It's different than just talking to someone over text or email.  A good relationship requires time to get to know each other. If one is going to be in a relationship for a long time then getting to know each other, figuring out their interests, etc should be part of the entire process.<n>A good relationship is also going out, doing something together, etc. A simple date is fun for a lot of people, but after a while you really don’
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Output: You decide which one you want.<n>Input:What kind of food should we eat the most? Choice: C  or E? Output: It depends<n>Input:which is the worst job? C or E? Output : A or B<n>Input:Which is the easiest job? C or E? Output: It depends<n><n>input:Which would be the best animal to work for in any country in the world? Choice: A or E? Output: A or B<n>Input :Whose favourite animal is? C or E? output: You decide<n><n>input:What colour is the black and white flag? Out of which choices we should choose the closest? Choice: B or C. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The museum made an odd choice for the koala display, they put the stuffed creature in what area where you'd usually find a panda? Choices:  A: jungle B: bamboo grove C: australian outback D: china E: child's book<n>Output:		The koala is in the garden of the Australian Outback<n>That's the best one<n><n>Input: The zoo put a giraffe in the same area as the otters. How did that make it easier?<n>Output: The otter's tail has a thicker part and a thinner part, the giraffe's tail has a thicker end and a thinner end, and the giraffe's tail is a different length. The giraffe and otter tails are equally large<n>So the giraffe isn't in the same area as otters<n>That's a bad answer<n><n>Question:The koala is kept in a room with a computer and a video player. The giraffe is kept in the jungle with a small screen and a computer. What is the distance from the computer to the giraffe's mouth?<n>Output: The kookaburra is in the garden of a tropical rainforest.<n>That's an easy one, the giraffe will be close if it has a screen (which shouldn't be much), but the kookaburra will always be at a far distance from the monitor (which should be much).<n><n>Question: The zoo lets you pet the koala. Which animal do you think it is most like?<n>Output: The orangutan is the closest because it has a trunk, but it's still not the most like the koala, the kangaroo would be close because of its tail and the armadillo is another close one because of its hands<n>So the least like the koala it is the orangutan (not including the kangaroo which has a long tail so it's the longest animal)<n>That's good, they're only animals<n><n>Question:The zoo has four rhinos. How many giraffes can they keep?<n>Output :<n>There are 4 giraffes<n>The giraffes are all near each other and you can pet one, as a giraffe needs a lot of space.<n>Now the most giraffes they can keep is 4!<n>Not a good answer to the question, the real answer is that the giraffes are a bit far away, even though I think the giraffe's are closer, it can be hard to tell from the photo since they don't have a big face to view.<n><n>Solution:<n>The animals that I think are closest are the giraffes, the otters, and the orangutans.<n>The zoo should do the giraffes
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where do you wait in a reception area for a meeting? Choices:  A: hall B: motel C: hotels D: law firm E: office building<n>Output:		You meet with a receptionist at the reception area  and say, “Hey I got your message last week.  I was wondering:  I would like to schedule a few more sessions with [the person in charge of recruiting students] if you’re open?  I’m in town this weekend through Saturday.  [If not, what time are you available on Friday?]”<n>So, in the first round you ask the receptionist where he/she will be at a certain time.  In the second round, then, you choose the receptionist based on who is in the most likely venue and then work your way from there.<n>In the third round you don’t even ask the receptionist where the meeting will be, because that would mean that you were trying to set it up with him/her.  Instead, you simply say “Hey, I’m in the office [the person will be in the office [the receptionist]] and I was wondering:  Would you like to meet with me on Monday [in the office.]”<n>If you have asked too many questions about the person in charge, then you have done it wrong.  There are many different scenarios where you should ask the person in charge.  In general, then, the questions you should ask are:  1) “Is there a time that would be convenient for you?”  In general if you get a “time that would be convenient for [person in charge]” and can’t figure out what it is, then you should stop there and go from there.  This is true even if the person is asking you a specific day and time.  Asking for a specific date is a better idea in most situations.  Then, in the fourth round, you ask how many questions you asked in each round.  If the answers include “5” or less, then you should stop and go from there.<n><n>Input:Adam is driving down the freeway in a car that cost $40,000.  Adam bought a car from Nissan for $25,000. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n>Output:		  You are the last person to drop the object. How did you go about doing it the correct way?<n> Input: The first two people in the room are eating pizza but only one of the two is looking. If you see an object in between them what do you do?<n> Output: If you make eye contact with the object, you have to drop the object. Otherwise, you keep eating the pizza.<n><n>Input:Mary is having an argument with her husband over something and the argument gets so bad that they decide not to have dinner together anymore so they can go to bed early. Do you?<n>Output: You decide not to go to dinner so you and your husband have a conversation without Mary knowing that anything is going on.   What are you most proud for?<n>Output: What decision you made earlier.<n><n>Input:After giving you and your husband a conversation without Mary knowing what is going on, what is the first thing you say to your wife?<n>Output: "I want to show you something."   What are you proud of?<n><n>Input:Mary finds a snake at an open field filled with dead animals. She decides not to kill the snake so that it can just die. Do you?<n> Output: Mary doesn't kill it because it already died. So she doesn't want to help it out either, she would just kill it just like she did with the dead dog.  ~~~<n>Output: Mary doesn't kill the snake and it dies in the open field because in that moment she felt that her father wanted her to kill the snake.<n><n>Input:John needs to have 5 people sign up to play. John makes them pay 50 cents for each game and makes them choose only three players. How many do you pick out of the 50?<n>Output: The people that were paying 50 cents each picked out 2 people each.<n>So John chose 3, for a total of 4, people<n><n>Input and Output:The person who gave you the 50 cents made you give him 5 of your favorite songs. You played them all!  How many songs were played?<n>Output: The person that gave you the 5 cents made you play every song he made in that order. How many songs would you choose?<n>Output: Since each song costs 5 cents, you only played 5 songs
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Which long saga will we be watching on tonight's program? Choices:  A: concert B: opera C: theater D: take class E: television<n>Output:		 Take class.<n><n>Submissions:<n>There will be NO REQUESTED SUBMISSIONS.<n>Submissions that follow these rules will be removed from the contest.<n><n>1: This contest is NOT a job application or resume review.<n>2: This contest is for FUN and to have fun.<n>3: No one can read your resumés or job applications.<n><n>Submission Form:<n><n>Please answer these multiple choice questions.<n>If you are unable to answer the questions correctly, you will lose points for each correct response.<n>You may submit more than 1 response in an attempt to get the most points, but if you submit more than 1 response, the contest administrator will need to review your responses to keep track of them.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n>Output:		 He took the bus to school A: bus B: taxi E: city centre<n>So he went to A*3x=3x1+1=3 (or bus B, if he was willing to walk there and back, or use C if the bus wasn't running) but he had to leave school A 10 minutes later than planned D and he had to take the taxi C but only needed to leave school B 5 minutes later. Therefore he needed 3 extra minutes each way to get home because the time between buses D and B was longer. So the real answer is 2/3<n><n>Input: What would you rather have a friend do with their vacation money - buy this or that? Output: You can either decide what to buy or send it to a friend (although at that point you probably have a lot of money to spend anyway)<n>So in this case the correct answer is both<n>Input: 1) buy<n>Output: 2), send it to a friend<n>In a previous lesson he needed to choose only one of these options and that was the correct answer.<n><n>Input: What are three of the three most common names for the American city New York City? Output:  3) Times Square 4) Broadway  5) Central Park<n>Output: 2) Times Square > Broadway > Central Park<n>Input: Who was born in New York City? Output?  John > James > John is James is John is John is John is Michael > Michael is Jodie is Jodie is James is Michael is Kevin is Kevin is John is Paul is Paul is John is James is Jim is Jim is Joester is Jose is Jose is Paul is Jose is John is James is James
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. If he gets them all out at the same time, then he uses them all right away. If he uses some for a while, then he's not done for that day. So it may take about a week for Adam to use all of his nuts and dried fruit.

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:During the brainstorming session there was a lot of talking and what? Choices:  A: obtaining information B: exchange of ideas C: sharing information D: conversation E: gathhering of information<n>Output:		 The following sentences are written:<n>-John gave the other group the information and discussed. -This was not a good idea because the information would be hard coded into the program. -We could not share information because the information would be in binary format.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Why is grooming often recommended to greasy teens? Choices:  A: neatness B: selfishness C: mistakes D: cleanliness E: satisfaction<n>Output:		 The best greasy teen is always clean and neat.  To achieve this standard greasy teens must:  A: Brush thoroughly B: Shave daily C: Wash their faces daily D: Avoid long hairs E: avoid eating grease F: eat greasy food on the reg F: avoid being greasy

But if you were to ask "what?" then you don't want germy germs in your mouth.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. The amount of yolk that needs to be dumped is 4 ounces but only 5.  The eggs are placed in a scale and the weight equals 4 ounces.  The customer buys 5 eggs.  The price added to the carton's total of 4 ounces is 2.55 - 2 = 0.58 ounces. The customer adds the total weight of the carton to the customer's check total.  The total is $5.25 - 1.25 = $4.50.  How much of the carton's total price was added to the customer's total price?<n>Output: 0.58 ounces subtracted from $5<n>So 0.55/(5-82)/(4+5) = $4.50<n><n>Input:A man went camping with his wife and their 10 children for several days.  She spent the day fishing, the second day cooking, the third day hiking, the fourth day camping, and the fifth day cleaning.  The total of her time spent by her 10 children was 14 hours.  The men did not fish that day and only spent an hour doing laundry.  How much time and money did the man spend fishing with his wife?<n>Output:14*0.29*2=22<n>So 4 hours (4*0.29)*2 = 44<n>So it was 44 times 4 hours (4*2)*2 = $440<n>So the final answer was $440<n><n>Input:A $20 bill comes into the bank. The teller asks, "How have you been?" The customer replies, "Oh, I've been well." The bank teller asks, "What caused you to be well?" ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:When playing baseball they keep track of mistakes, this stat is called what? Choices:  A: happiness B: sore muscles C: injury D: perfection E: errors<n>Output:		 Errors are the ball hitting a runner's head and then the ball hitting the runner.  Errors can happen when anyone throws the ball.  Errors can also happen when the batter hits the ball and then the error hits the runner.<n>Output: 100%<n><n>It’s pretty difficult to put into practice for a beginner. I don’t think the “correct” way to learn is to try to do it in the real world. You would never be able to judge which of the questions are right out of the gate because you couldn’t apply that knowledge to any other question. So if you were going to answer that question incorrectly without a prior understanding then you would need to learn a lot more than you would expect.<n><n>For the record, I have a question about this particular question. If an answer is incorrect, would this cause that person to be labeled as non-perfecter?<n><n>I'd say no.<n><n>You can’t get a perfect rating on all six questions, so it would make more sense if the number of questions in a set was based on your answers to the six questions of that set. After all, if someone gets a perfect score on three questions then they are in the 99% percentile across all six questions regardless of which category they fall on. I know this question appears to be phrased as if you get perfect answers on all six questions but this is false.<n>If the questions are all correct then people will not be labeled as perfectionists, so it's fair to say that "perfecte[d]t" will not always be the name used for a person at a given time.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n>Output:		<n><n>Input: How much do you normally spend each month on groceries?<n>Output: According to this table, I spend around 1,500$.<n><n>Input: What percentage of your time do you spend working?<n>Output: According the this table, I spend approximately 40%. (I'm at work for 8 in the morning. When I'm home in the afternoon, I work from five until seven. In between, I spend time with friends and family.)<n>Output: What is this table showing?<n><n>Input: On what day of the week do you make less than $200? Answer: Any day on a Wednesday<n>Output: Any day on Monday<n>So on Tuesday I would lose $200, Wednesday I would earn $200 and Thursday I would spend $200 on food and drink.<n><n>Input: If there is a job in which all employees are paid at the same salary, how many could be hired? Answer: 1,000 answers<n> output: 3,000<n> so you will have 1,000*1,000=3,000 employees<n> so this means you will have 3,000*3,000=9,000 employees<n> so you will have 9,000*9,000=32,000 workers<n> so this means you need 64,000*16,000=128,000 workers<n> so you need 128*16,000=384,000 workers<n> so a total of 384,000*32,000 = 192,000 people<n> so you need 144,000*16,800=288,000 people<n> so 192,000*16,200=384,000 people<n> so 384,000*16,140=320,000 people<n> so 288,000*16,120=384,000 people (384,000*16,144=288,000)<n> so 384,000+16,120=384k=64k<n>so 64k+16,120=128k (64k+16,120+384k)<n>so 32k+16,120-384k=1,000 (64*2,963)(384k)/2k = 1,000$<n> so 1,000$/2k = 8$, in other words 64k/963$ = 8$<n> so 1,100$/2k = 9$, in other words 256$/2k = 10$<n> so 10$/2k = 12$, in other words 192$/2k = 20$

When you arrive at school on Tuesday, February 9, you will spend six hours getting to know the faculty. Two hours per week you will ask teachers questions and give answers based on those questions.  On Wednesday you will spend six hours talking to the profs about your problems.  Then on Thursday you will spend another six hours with the profs.  Finally, after you get your diploma, you'll spend two more hours with the profs discussing any problems that have come up the previous two days.  Does this sounds reasonable to you?<n>Input: Yes, sounds reasonable to me.<n>Output - each question costs one hour of your time per week.<n>Output - every other question costs three hours of your time per week, and only two hours of that is spent asking a question. If you divide $2 by three, you pay $15 for a week of class time.
