The University of California is an equal opportunity provider and educator. All members of the University of California must understand that they hold the same rights and obligations as other members of the University. This website is not designed to cover all subjects in all areas.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:The man on the street corner was showing off a wristwatch, he was trying to what it for drug money? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: case C: hock D: watch store E: pawn<n>Output:		 Watch C<n><n>Input: A man was in a barbershop and asked to be booked. The barber asked, "What are you looking for?" "I need this woman to marry me." The man said, "You'll have to ask her, I've never seen her before." The barber told him to have a seat, took off a comb, then offered him a comb as a replacement. "But why would I want to marry my comb?" the man asked. The barber said she would cut his hair for $30 a month. The man asked, "But why would I marry a comb?"<n>The barber said she would keep the comb, he wouldn't lose any hair and she would keep her position as his lifeguard. But what would he do for the money?<n>Input: There were five cars parked in front of a restaurant, and three young men, including myself, were going into the restaurant. We were not going to eat at the restaurant, we wished to visit the restroom. The manager of the restaurant suggested that we go into the store and purchase some cigarettes for each of us. The manager gave one of the men a free pack of cigarettes. The two other men were very happy to take this deal. But my friend and I were very disappointed in the manager. The manager had not given our friend a pack of cigarettes, yet he had provided a free pack of cigarettes for each of our friend. When we asked why, the manager answered that he did not have enough cigarettes to allow us to purchase two packs of cigarettes. We agreed to leave immediately, because we did not feel a connection with the owner. We could not wait to return that night. The manager then made a $3 bet with my friend that he could not get into the store without our friend's permission, no matter what.<n>Input: Two men bought six packets of peanut butter at a store. In the store they left a receipt but the store clerk did not recognize any person from the receipt. The men were very upset. The men asked for the clerk to go to the back and return the receipt. The clerk came back with the receipt and the two men were very happy, except that the clerk did not know the name of one of the men. The clerk then asked the two men who they were. The two men refused to tell the man's name, so the clerk took all of the money they had and went back to the back to get a list of everyone from the receipt. The clerk realized
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n>Output:		 He was getting up... His eyes looked blurry.  His legs weren't moving properly and his arms were stiff. He had a feeling that all the muscles in his body were tired out. He then became aware that he was on his back. He could tell by the feel of his chest that he was breathing pretty heavily.<n>So the final question is: Was he tired?<n><n>Input:A student was studying for his physics final and realized that he was having trouble concentrating.  So he went into the bathroom to take a nap. Which bathroom?<n>Output: The farthest left  The farthest right  The center of the room<n>The farthest left farthest right farthest center<n><n>Input:Two people were out in the park sitting on a bench. A man named Peter sat down right beside Susan.  What did Susan say?  Outbox: "This is a nice place for a couple to sit and chat. I find parks much easier to relax in alone."<n>Output: Peter got up  "Yeah, it is nice, a really nice place and we have a lot to talk about. I'm wondering, did you have anyone over last night?"<n>So the final question:<n><n>Input:Bill is running down the stairs.  He needs to catch up on the laundry that he forgot to put away before leaving for school.  How does he get down the stairs?<n>Output: Walk  Run (no time)  Use a ladder<n>It is very hard to walk up the stairs  To be able to run down the stairs he need to use stairs<n>So the final question for this round:<n><n>Input: A student went to get her coffee and found her bag had fallen on the floor. Which of the following will it belong to?<n>output: Bag of Coffee<n>So it belonged to the bag of coffee<n><n>Input: A young man is in the shower. He hears a strange sound in the bathroom. He doesn't know what it is and can't get out of the shower because the curtain is over his head. After some time, he tries to pull the curtain away but it won't budge. He then opens it and sees several women walking into the bathroom. What did he say?<n>Output: "There you are, so glad I could get you out of the shower!  And all you did was pee, no need to leave that big mess behind you!"  Susan didn't believe him but when he opened his mouth to respond she laughed.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:What kind of radio does someone use to reach base? Choices:  A: vessel B: box C: transistor D: submarine E: lamp<n>Output:		 One kilowatt of power per kilometer travelled.<n><n>Input: What is the size of the largest object whose mass can be calculated with a 1-dimensional calculus?<n>Output: 14.6 million kg<n>What is the height of the tallest man alive?<n>Output: 9.5 metres<n>What is the weight of water in kilograms?<n>Output: 2.25 grams<n>Which mass is 2.25 times heavier than the earth?<n>Output: 1 billion kilogram<n>Which mass is twice the earth's?<n>Output: 5 million kilos.<n>Which mass is three times the earth's?<n>output: 8.2 million kilogram<n>Which mass has two times the radius of earth's orbit?<n><n>Input: What's the name of the last thing Bill Gates said and the last thing Tom Cruise said in a movie? Choices: Bill Gates said What's the name of your home and your car?" and Tom Cruise said Which house is cheaper to own?" and Bill Gates said Which is more likely to flood?" and Tom Cruise said Why is the sky blue in California and Greenland?" and Bill Gates said which side of the ocean is the north and which is the south? Choices: Bill said Which is bigger?" and Tom said Which is faster..." and Bill said which is cheaper?" and Tom said Which side has more houses and car parks?" and Bill said<n>Output: 7.5 million US dollars (£4.4 million) and a submarine.<n><n>Input: Which of the following is an example of a generalization rule?<n>Output: If the weight and size of a object are related then the weight of a box must decrease by at least half.<n><n>Input: If I were to tell you that I am a professional in a field which only I can say anything about, what would you most likely not believe? Choices: I will say nothing about that field. I will say nothing about my profession. I will say something about my profession.<n>Output: 7.17 million US dollars (£4,000)<n><n>Input: What difference can you make between two different shapes of triangles? You are allowed to add or subtract pieces of any shape to make a new triangle.  If both sides of one face are less than the other side, say, and the other two are more equal, say, than any of the other triangles we have, which is the right triangle? Choices: A and B Both of B Both of C None of B<n>Output: I

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. He

A: liquor store B: liquor store C: bar D: bar E: liquor store<n>So now let's suppose that the mannequin was made from solid wood, you could take the value of the wooden mannequin and take its weight of the wood and that is the value of a full bottle of wine, but the mannequin does not touch the liquid alcohol which is why it should be equal to the mannequin weight.<n><n>Output : Take the value of the wooden material, and it is equal to its weight.<n>Output : Take the values of metal material and it is equal to metal weight minus a value of liquid material.<n><n>Input: You can buy a car from a seller for $4000. You are not allowed to ask the seller who your bank account belongs to so that it will appear in your bank statement.  The seller also needs  $200 up front or the transaction will be canceled. The $200 up front,  $4000 in goods or services,  the value of the car or truck is all based on agreed upon values. Your bank account belongs to your account and the terms are the agreed upon value of such goods or services. At the end of each day, you report for duty and taxes. You then pay the taxes but you do not receive the goods or services in exchange. How many days would each part take?  Output: Days<n>The answer is 7.  In a country with only 1 tax it takes about 8 days to collect the taxes by the bank and pay the seller.  But if the buyer pays taxes, and the seller pays sales taxes, then it takes only 8 days. But if the seller also pays a sales tax (VAT), then it takes 9 days to complete the transaction but if the seller also pays taxes, then it takes 9 days.  So in this instance, the seller needs to pay sales tax or the transaction will not be completed.<n><n>Input: A farmer is offered a cow for $2000.  He takes the cow from the seller.  The buyer can buy the cow back at a later date for $3000. How many cows is the farmer going to use? The answers:<n>Input: A Farmer   a. Wants to sell his cow at $1000.  But for the rest of the cow's life he is going to make use of it<n>Output: A cow that will be sold for $1000 is going to serve to make use
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input:It was breakfast time.  Brad ordered eggs, toast, and something to drink. What might he drink? Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n>Output:		 It was breakfast time.  It was 2 pm. He ate breakfast. He had some coffee and put some toast in his mouth. Then he decided to take a walk. He walked for about 10 minutes and came back home. He drank some coffee and then threw up. He had a sandwich with some coffee for lunch and took a walk again. He had coffee in his morning break. So he spent 2 consecutive hours at his place of work. So the final answer is 2<n><n>Input:There was a meeting with a large management company. The CEO and the other company executives came for the meeting. John had the meeting with them. How much time did he spend at the meeting?<n>Output: He spent two hours at the meeting<n><n>Input:Diana was driving home when she saw some suspicious activity on 4th street. She stopped for gas. As she was filling up her tank, a woman, about 5 feet 5 inches tall with long straight hair walked up to her. Diana got out of her car and called 911. The other driver, a black male, pulled up next to Diana. He asked her questions. When he was done she asked him questions. When he left her car Diana asked her, "why did he ask me that?". She replied, "He asked me, why did he do that?" He, replied, "I don't know what he did, but he did something funny." They both laughed. The woman drove off, but Diana followed her. The woman asked if she was from Detroit. She replied, "no, I'm not from Detroit." He replied, "why did you stop her?" Diana replied, "Because she did have a very distinctive voice." They both laughed. Diana followed the woman for a few blocks until they turned onto West Grand Boulevard and she let Diana know that the woman had told her everything that she had told 911. Diana, replied, "what does she look like?" She replied, "I don’t know" The woman asked her if she was a detective. Diana replied, "No, I am a forensic investigator.
